Keywords:
Gossypium hirsutum, seedling diseases, Rhizoctonia rot,
Fusarium oxysporum
Abstract:
Cotton is a billion-dollar crop in Australia, especially
in regional areas of New South Wales (NSW) and Queensland. Fusarium wilt
caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.Â sp. vasinfectum (Fov) is of an important
disease in cotton globally and in Australia. The Australian cotton
industry is currently adopting highly resistant cultivars to Fov.
Therefore, it is believed that Fusarium wilt pressure will be minimal on
the cotton crop. However, a total of 188 putative Fusarium isolates were
recovered from cotton seedlings exhibited atypical symptoms of either
Fusarium damping-off or Fusarium wilt, which were sampled across NSW
during the 2017/18 and 2018/19 seasons. On the basis of sequence
analysis of the translation elongation factor 1-alpha (TEF1), eight
Fusarium species were identified that being Fusarium oxysporum, F.
equesiti and F. falciforme species complex, F. nygamai, F.
brachygibbosum, F. acuminatum, F. chlamydosporum, and F. redolens. Of
these, F. oxysporum species complex (FOSC) accounted for over 80% of the
total number of isolates recovered. The predominant number of isolates
(78.5%) were clustered with non-Australian Fov race 1-8. The remaining
21.5% of FOSC isolates in our study was clustered with Australian Fov
biotypes. This short communication is the first TEF1-based assessment of
Fusarium diversity associated with Rhizoctonia-like diseased cotton
seedlings sampled across NSW, Australia.
